examples out there so first let's talk about what is xamarin so xamarin lets
you build Android iOS apps with Visual Studio Visual Studio and c-sharp okay
it's built on the mono framework which is a cross-platform implementation of dotnet and if you use Visual Studio 2017
or Visual Studio for Mac it's automatically included with that or it can be downloaded as an option okay
samer comes with its own compiler and it gives access to each platforms SDK okay
which means that you can work with Android code you can work with iOS code libraries there's there's tools that you
can use to bring in libraries that already exist and you can work with those and then you can also use c-sharp
libraries that already exist so you can use it to bring in some your favorite net NuGet packages and work with those
okay so xamarin is think of it as a kind of a cross-platform
implementation so that you can share code between multiple platforms if you want you can have your shared logic you
know think of it as like the business layer it can all be written in c-sharp and then some of the user interface can
be written in c-sharp as well and you can share that things like just you know logic and navigation and things like
that but then you get into platform specific code which is the native iOS
the native Android and if you're if you're doing Windows Phone the native Windows Phone UI layer
okay so we'll kind of talk about what is what can be shared between the platforms
and what has to stay within a certain platform but using xamarin you can
create mobile phone apps you can create tablet apps you can create apps for your
watch okay so xamarin gives you the ability to kind of open the door for is
particularly if you come from a more of a dotnet development back work background if you're familiar with c-sharp if you're familiar with Visual
Studio it gives you the ability to expand that that code base that you're
used to working with and expand out into mobile platforms it also gives you
native performance so for native iOS what you see is you have dotnet code or
c-sharp code using the.net library and then bindings that bring in c-sharp code
or bring in I'm sorry bring in iOS code and those ultimately get compiled down
to application files which then run natively on the platform then the same
goes for Android you have your dotnet code or dotnet libraries c-sharp code
bindings it all compiles down into an apk ultimately it runs natively on the Android platform so really what you're
seeing is as close to native performance as you're gonna get without actually using native so Android or salmon kind
of helps compile things down into the real runtimes as far as development
system requirements go for iOS how many of you are Mac users primarily okay so
rough we have if you're gonna do iOS you have to have a Mac somewhere in the development pipeline okay it has to have
a minimum of ten with Yosemite or beyond and you have to have Visual Studio for
Mac and Xcode installed now optionally if you want to do xamarin iOS you can
also work with the Windows PC but at as I said at some point the code has to
compiled on a Mac especially if you're gonna deploy to the store so at some point in your pipeline you have to have
a Mac and whether that's maybe something in the cloud you can use you know a third-party provider something like that
but you can do i OS development on your Windows machine you just have to have at
least Visual Studio 2012 you have to have the xamarin plugin which it comes automatically with Visual Studio 2017
and as I said it still has to have some sort of network connectivity to the Mac
particularly if you want to debug on the simulator now for Android there's a
little bit more flexibility okay you can work on a Mac with OS 10 Yosemite and

gonna deploy to a physical device you have to deploy from Mac yes question ah

ah okay I'm gonna have to live with it I guess is that Alright okay my apologies
so testing on iOS you have to have a Mac on Android there's a number of different

the environment or emulating the environment so it's not really the real thing but it gives you kind of an
approximation it lets you let you play around lets you work with your work with
what looks like a device and I'll show you what that looks like on your on your machine you don't have to have a physical device if you don't want and
just kind of ease of use as far as deploying your test application to the simulator and the emulator just it works
really nice however you want to do real device testing as well okay so emulators
and simulators as I said are only an approximation they're not actually the real thing so there's going to be different constraints and limitations as
an example I wrote for an Android application many years ago I wrote a take a picture of a check and deposit it
you know to your account for a major financial institution and we found that there was one particular device that
didn't have enough memory to handle taking the picture and do the processing that in the way that we anticipated that
we were gonna do so we had to refactor some things so that that was something we didn't find on our simulator our on
the emulator we didn't find it on a lot of the devices we we had to play around and we started getting feedback from customers that there was this one
particular device that it didn't work all that well with so physical devices just there's a wide range of physical
devices that you can test on that you really need to test on and you need to think about what your users are actually
using okay and again you want to test on multiple devices so don't just pick one
device don't don't just pick your personal device you know that that's a great way to go if it's your personal
device there's a pretty good chance that other people are using that same device however with the broad range
particularly on the Android side with the broad range of devices out there there's you have to really have a
of a large test suite of devices to play with so building applications with
xamarin there's some questions that you want to ask yourself before you really get started okay are you going to be
targeting multiple platforms are you shooting for Android you shooting for iOS are you going to be using the same
code for anything on the window side in particular are you hoping to reuse some
of that same functionality in that same code and that same logic okay the reason
you want to think about this in advance is because it's going to help drive how you structure your code and how your how
you interact with the different layers of your code so if you're gonna reuse
your code you need to know the difference between UI specific code and common logic okay so UI specific code is
that code that interacts with actual UI elements so things like if a button click happens this code gets executed if
like a text field gets changed and you want to grab the the values from that text field this code gets executed
things like that anything that's common that doesn't actually interface with the
user interface at all that's more agnostic of the UI and so that can be considered common logic if you want to
get into reusing code between azam or an android project and a xamarin iOS project you want to keep that common
logic separate in a separate project structure so that means you're gonna
create UI specific projects for Android and iOS assuming that you want to share
and you want to create UI agnostic projects for that common logic so anything that is shared services you
know business logic things like that anything that does not touch the UI that's considered your common logic
that's going to be UI agnostic if you're working on it with a team that is doing
Android and iOS development and they're not necessarily the same developers I'm
you know you might want to consider having just separate solutions this is a minor thing but Android developers if
they particularly if they're working on a Windows machine if they open up the solution they may have an issue with
every single time they open up the solution the project doesn't load properly and they may have some compilation issues if they
aren't there to have a matter if they don't have a Mac in their pipeline to build so just kind of as a courtesy you
want to consider separating those out just a separate solution that is android-specific stuff and then of
course you're gonna have the shared shared stuff there as well and then iOS specific stuff now as far as how you
share these projects I would recommend dotnet standard these days so doubt net
standard it's a set of api's that all dotnet platforms have to implement so
it's they basically it's a standard that everybody attains and then it unifies
all the dotnet platforms okay and then what the benefit of that is and and and
xamarin does support down that standard the benefit of that is that you can start to bring in libraries from all
over the place and just know that it's going to work on your platform and you can have you can write logic in your
common logic projects that you can use on more than just your xamarin projects okay so dotnet standard brings a lot of
power particularly in the code sharing space the biggest drawback to this is
that any reference to assemblies any assemblies that you need to bring into your project also have to support down as standard so it's kind of once you go
down that standard you're kind of going all in but these days that's becoming less and less of an issue and overall it's it's
worked very well for me on the projects that I've been on since dotnet standard has come out and so I'd recommend at
least checking that out now the way you actually implement these is you put your
common code into a dotnet standard project and then you put your platform-specific code into
platform-specific projects and then you reference that common code okay and
again things that are common are things like your models your view models your
converters value converters and then any services anything that maybe connects to web services or databases or you know
how ever it is that you're going to work whether it's a local database or connecting to a web service remotely to hit a remote database pretty much
anything that is not touching the UI no structure is gonna be fairly simple
but there are some things to keep in mind again if you're doing Android and iOS so your iOS project is going to have
your UI code and it's gonna have your controllers your view controllers okay
the Android project is going to have your UI code and then it's going to have your activities Android has activities
iOS has view controllers conceptually they're fairly similar but they are different implementations and so you
want to have a different structure for each one of them and then you're gonna have a core library or libraries it can
be more than one and that's where you're gonna have your business logic you're gonna have your services you're gonna have your data access anything like that
okay any questions so far feel free to just raise a hand if you have a question let's start with xamarin

manifest so layouts are files that define the UI okay in an Android and in

views you place your controls and then you can assign IDs so that your activities then later can reference

resources folder or within the resources folder in a folder called layout and even though it's actually XML that
you're seeing in xamarin Android it's a dot a XML file ok what's interesting is
you can take the exact same code from a native Android project in an XML layout
file and drop it verbatim into a dot a XML file for xamarin Android and it's

graphic assets are things like graphic files that are used by the UI and they're placed in the resources folder

the drawable folder or underneath the resources folder so there's multiple drawables drawable folders so it kind of
gets interesting as an example there's the drawable hdpi which means high
density pixel whatever the eye is I can't remember but there's like high
extra high extra extra high and you know so on
so if you're gonna support multiple densities then you need to have multiple
density folders okay and so that means you're gonna have images within these folders that are scaled differently so
you're not gonna have just the same full or the same image that's gonna be massive that's going to scale to a small device you're gonna have images that are
scaled accordingly to each of these supported densities okay and as I said
there's it even starts with the L dpi and then mdpi hdpi and it goes all the way up to three X's hdpi okay so string
values with Android think of it as kind of a string resources file if you're familiar with Windows development you
have the resources the string resources file the strings file is the exact same
thing on Android you define all your strings that are shown in the UI and then you place them in resources slash
values folder in a file called strings.xml the benefit of this is then
you automatically get easier globalization you don't have to go and refactor later to do globalization it
just automatically is baked in you know you can have different versions for different languages activities so
activities these are the things that actually interpret interact with your user interface okay so it's going to
respond to input it's gonna drive the user experience it's gonna respond to lifecycle events activities are really

are a little bit different and it's that implementation that we're going to talk about right now that makes it kind of a little bit unique to xamarin Android so
the first thing that you need to do if you're going to implement an activity is decorate the activity with an activity attribute and what this does is it
signals the Android manifest that this is this is an activity that is included in the application so I said kind of
leading with the Android manifest file that you define your activities with a native Android application that's true

is now running which is that kind of gray area if the activity gets put into
the background maybe gets another activity gets pushed on top of it maybe another app gets pushed on top of
it eventually it gets pushed down the stack and kind of put to sleep for a little while then it's gonna call on
pause and then on stop okay and from the on pause method it can get cycled back
again and go back into on resume and then be running so at just about any point in here you can see the arrows

activity comes back again okay so if the activity actually gets pushed into the background and gets called to stop then

how many of you are unit testers okay some people are kind of half-hearted
about it other you others are into it I'm a fan of unit testing I really find
a lot of value in it and so I like to implement unit tests on my projects and so as a result I've learned that there's
a couple of different ways that you can implement unit testing on your projects you can do UI tests these are tests that
are think of it as like actual interactions with buttons and things like that so there's a number of
different ways you can do it and a number of different Suites but one particular example is the xamarin dot UI test project so you can create a UI test
project using the xamarin tooling that then runs as part of your visual studio
unit test suite and then ultimately you can deploy that to the xamarin test
cloud and it'll run on an a whole suite of devices okay so you can make sure that the the button clicks happen you
know as expected on it you know a number of different devices and things like that so you can kind of work with the user interface aspect then you can get
into platform specific tests that are not necessarily related to the UI but
like let's say maybe you've got particular components that need to you know be executed on Android or on iOS
and they're different on the different platforms you can write platforms specific test projects and when these
run they'll run on either a simulator for iOS or an emulator for Android or they can be run on the physical device
and essentially what it is is it's an application that gets deployed and run and that application then runs the unit
tests on that device and so you can make sure that you're getting like real platform specific tests and and code and
making sure that it's you know maybe calling out to the database the local database as expected and things like that things that maybe aren't
necessarily cross-platform you can make sure that it works the way you'd expect then you can get into kind
of more platform agnostic stuff and this is where dotnet standard really comes into play you can you can create a
dotnet core test project which which implements the dotnet standard then you can reference your dotnet standard
libraries from what we talked about earlier and then once you run these tests they
run completely agnostic of the platform so you don't ever have to run you don't have to spool up a simulator or an
emulator okay so the test run within Visual Studio as part of your visual studio unit test suite and there's no
real concern about having to wait for the simulator but then you don't have platform specific code that can be
executed with these either so you kind of have three different approaches that you can fully test your application if
you want in an automated fashion so I've
been working with xamarin for a number of years now on a number of different types of projects and so I've got some
thoughts on my experiences with it so strengths I came from a very heavy net
background working with C sharp and Visual Studio so for me the fact that I can continue to work with C sharp with
Visual Studio I find that to be a strength it gives me the ability to have
native look and feel in my applications while still being in that familiar development environment you can reuse a
lot of your code a lot of it especially if you do a really good job of defining
kind of that UI agnostic stuff and having good separation of you know UI
specific things from that agnostic stuff you can reuse a lot of your code if you use dotnet standard then you can start
to pull in new get packages you can create new kit packages you can reference those same packages in in
projects that aren't even necessarily xamarin projects because of the support of net standard so there's there's a ton
of support for code reuse when working with xamarin now weaknesses again I came
